unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: Margin of Error
question_text: A local news station was covering a city council race and said that Candidate $A$ was polling ahead of Candidate $B$ with $52\%$ of voters favoring Candidate $A$ . The news station also stated their results come with a margin of error of $3\%$ . What is believed to be the true proportion of voters who favor Candidate $A$ ?
solution:
When a random sample is taken, the sample proportion will rarely equal the true population proportion. In this case, the sample proportion produced a ^ p = 0.52 p ^ = 0.52 or 52 % 52 % . But, this value came with a margin of error, so the news station does believes that the value of 52 % 52 % is a good starting point, but might not be exactly correct. The news station believes the true population proportion will be:

52 % ± 3 % 52 % ± 3 %

Therefore, they believe the true proportion who favor candidate A A to be somewhere between 49 % 49 % and 55 % 55 %

Choice 'A' is correct.
